case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 1084-1091 of 1967 and 1081 of 1970

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1084, 1091 of 1967 and 1081 of 1970 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1084 1091 of 1967 and 1081 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from Judgment and order dated 9th June 1966 of Mysore High Court in W.Ps. Nos. 442, 884 and 441 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the Judgment and order dated the 9th June 1966 of the Mysore High Court in W.Ps. Nos. 442, 884 and 441 of 1964.

facts.text: Three appeals from judgments dated 9 June 1966, 10 December 1964 and 19 July 1966 of Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals are by certificate from the judgments dated 9 June, 1966, 10 December, 1964 and 19 July, 1966 of the High Court of Mysore.

facts.text: On 8 April 1963, Regional Transport Authority South Kanara issued notification under Section 57(2) inviting applications from public carriers permit holders of South Kanara District to operate in Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: On 8 April, 1963, the Regional Transport Authority, South Kanara issued a numberification under Section 57 2  of the Act inviting applications from public carriers permit holders  if South Kanara District intending to operate their vehicles in the State of Maharashtra.

facts.text: Permits under reciprocal agreement between Mysore and Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: The permits were under reciprocal agreement between the State Governments of Mysore and Maharashtra.

facts.text: 28 vacancies for permits, 39 applications received.

anchor.surface_text: There were 28 vacancies for permits. 39 applications were made for the same.

facts.text: Respondent Kamath submitted application for permit in Civil Appeal No. 1084 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Kamath in Civil Appeal No. 1084 of 1967 submitted an application for permit.

facts.text: Kamath's application rejected by Regional Transport Authority Mangalore.

anchor.surface_text: His application was rejected by the Regional Transport Authority, Mangalore.

facts.text: Kamath appealed to State Transport Appellate Tribunal, appeal rejected.

anchor.surface_text: He preferred an appeal to the State Transport Appellate Tribunal. The State Transport Appellate Tribunal rejected the appeal.

facts.text: Inter-State Transport Commission issued directions under section 63A(2)(c) laying down order of preference for grant of permits.

anchor.surface_text: The Inter-State Transport Commission issued certain direc- tions to the Regional Transport Authorities. These directions were issued under section 63A 2  c  of the Act. These directions laid down the order of preference in the grant of permits.

facts.text: Transport Authorities followed the directions of Inter-State Transport Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The Transport Authorities kept in view those directions

facts.text: Respondent Kamath filed application under Article 226 to Mysore High Court challenging Transport Authorities' decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Kamath made an application under Article 226 of the Constitution to the Mysore High Court.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held that directions by Inter-State Transport Commission encroached on quasi-judicial jurisdiction of Regional Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that the directions issued by the Inter-State Transport Commission encroached on the quasi-.judicial jurisdiction of the Regional Transport Authority.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority Belgaum on 20 September 1963 invited applications for variation of permits including three new inter-State routes to Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Belgaum on 20 September, 1963 invited applications under section 57 2  of the Act from operators holdig substantive public carrier permits issued by that Authority for variation of the companyditions of permit by the inclusion of three new straight inter-State routes between the places in Belgaum District, companynecting with places lying in Maharashtra State in the said permit and for grant of companynter-signature by the State Transport Authority, Maharashtra under the reciprocal agreement between the two States.

facts.text: 25 applications received for Belgaum permits, respondent Jaknur's rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of applications was 25. The application of respondent Jaknur was rejected.

facts.text: Inter-State Transport Commission issued directions on 3 October 1963 for Belgaum case.

anchor.surface_text: The Inter-State Transport Commission on 3 October, 1963 issued directions indicating the order of preference in the matter of grant of permits.

facts.text: Respondent Jaknur filed application under Article 226 to Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Jaknur thereupon made an application under Article 226 of the Constitution to the Mysore High Court.

facts.text: High Court accepted contentions of respondent Jaknur.

anchor.surface_text: The companytentions of the respondent Jaknur found favour with the High Court.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority on 26 September 1963 called applications for inter-signature by Kerala STA for Mysore-Kerala routes.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority on 26 September, 1963 called from owners of carriers who had been granted permits applications for grant of companynter-signature by the Kerala State Transport Authority. for plying of vehicles on routes between the States of Mysore and Kerala.

facts.text: Respondent Hegde's application rejected because not in position to command facilities to public.

anchor.surface_text: His application was, rejected. The principal ground for rejection of the application was that the respondent Hegde was number in a position to companymand facilities to the public.

facts.text: Respondent Hegde filed application under Article 226 before Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Hegde thereupon filed an application under Article 226 of the Constitution before the Mysore High Court.

facts.text: Directions by Commission gave preference: 1. Co-operative Society (50% members not related, 75% employees, main business transport). 2. Other Transport Co-op Societies. 3. Limited company or registered firm. 4. Others.

anchor.surface_text: The directions issued by the inter-State Transport Commission under section 63A  2   c  were inter alia these Preference will be given in the following order in the grant of the permits. A Co-operative Society at least 50 per cent of the members of which are number related to each other 75 per cent of the members of which are also employees and the main business of which is the provision of transport services. Transport Co-operative Societies other than the above. A limited companypany or a registered firm. Others.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court order quashing the directions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was companyrect in holding that the Commission was number vested with any power to issue directions which may have the effect of fettering the Regional Transport Authorities or the State Transport Authorities companycerned in performance of their quasi-judicial functions under the provisions of the Act. The order of the High Court in quashing the direction is upheld.

facts.text: Appeals fail.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail.

facts.text: Respondents did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents did number appear.
section 63A 2  c  of the Motor Vebicles Act

issues.text: Whether the Inter-State Transport Commission was competent to issue directions under section 63A(2)(c) of the Motor Vehicles Act laying down the order of preference in the grant of permits

anchor.surface_text: The principal point for companysideration in these appeals is whether the InterState Transport Commission was companypetent to do so.

issues.text: Whether the directions issued by the Inter-State Transport Commission invaded, infringed and impinged on the authority and jurisdiction of the Transport Authorities for the grant of permits thereby vitiating their decisions

anchor.surface_text: The main grounds for challenge were these. The InterState Transport Commission issued directions to the Transport Authorities indicating the order of preference for grant of permits. The Transport Authorities became bound by and kept in view these directions. These directions invaded, infringed and impinged on the authority and jurisdiction of the Transport Authorities for the grant of perpmits. Therefore the decisions of the Transport Authorities were vitiated.

issues.text: Whether the power under section 63A(2)(c) permits directions that trench upon or fetter the quasi-judicial functions of State or Regional Transport Authorities in granting permits

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the directions issued by the Inter-State Transport Commission encroached on the quasi-.judicial jurisdiction of the Regional Transport Authority.

issues.text: Whether delegation of legislative power can be inferred from the power to issue directions under section 63A(2)(c) absent explicit rule-making authority

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any power to enact subordinate legislation by way of rules the delegation of legislative power cannot be lightly inferred.

issues.text: Whether the interpretation of section 43A in B. Rajagopala Naidu applies to section 63A(2)(c) limiting directions to administrative matters

anchor.surface_text: section 43A of the Act... This Court held that the power of the State Government to issue orders and directions... did number embrace any power... to give directions in respect of matters... dealt with... in quasi-judicial manner.

arguments.claim: The directions issued by the Inter-State Transport Commission invaded, infringed and impinged on the authority and jurisdiction of the Transport Authorities for the grant of permits thereby vitiating their decisions

anchor.surface_text: The main grounds for challenge were these. The InterState Transport Commission issued directions to the Transport Authorities indicating the order of preference for grant of permits. The Transport Authorities became bound by and kept in view these directions. These directions invaded, infringed and impinged on the authority and jurisdiction of the Transport Authorities for the grant of permits. Therefore the decisions of the Transport Authorities were vitiated.

arguments.claim: Under section 63A(2)(c) the Inter-State Transport Commission was competent to issue directions to the State or Regional Transport Authorities regarding grant of permits, including indicating order of preference as criteria

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that under section 63A 2 c of the Act the Inter-State Transport Commission was competent to. issue directions to the State or the Regional Transport Authorities regarding grant of permits, and, therefore, the indicating of order of preference in the directions amounted only to laying down criteria to be applied in dealing with permits.

arguments.court_reasoning: Power limited to executive and administrative directions, not fettering quasi-judicial functions

arguments.claim: The reasoning in Naidu case does not apply to section 63A(2)(c) because it speaks only of 'directions' and not 'orders and directions'

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the reasoning in Naidus case supra could not apply to the interpretation of section 63A 2 c of the Act which spoke only of directions and not of orders and directions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dicial functions and their orders are quasi-judicial orders. It is, therefore essential to

arguments.court_reasoning: Contention unsound on logic and principle

arguments.claim: Section 43A directions cannot interfere with quasi-judicial functions of transport authorities (per Naidu case)

anchor.surface_text: This Court in B. Rajagopala Naidu v. State Transport Appellate Tribunal Ors. construed section 43A of the Motor Vehicles Act... held that the power of the State Government to issue orders and directions... did not embrace any power... to give directions in respect of matters... dealt with... in quasi-judicial manner.

arguments.claim: By analogy to section 43A in Naidu, section 63A(2)(c) directions cannot trench on quasi-judicial functions

anchor.surface_text: The words orders and directions were held in that case to be equivalent to executive acts. Those words could cover only the field of administrative orders and directions. This Court said that the structure of the Act indicated that section 43A of the Act did not include the area which is the subject-matter of the exercise of quasi-judicial authority.

arguments.claim: In absence of rule-making power, delegation of legislative power cannot be lightly inferred for directions under 63A(2)(c)

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any power to enact subordinate legislation by way of rules the delegation of legislative power cannot be lightly inferred.

arguments.claim: Section 63A(4) requiring authorities to give effect to directions indicates they are administrative, not legislative

anchor.surface_text: The provisions, contained in section 63A 4 of the Act are that where the Commission... issues directions to the State or the Regional Transport Authorities, those authorities shall give effect and will be guided by such directions.

arguments.claim: Transport authorities exercise quasi-judicial functions in grant of permits; decisions must not be clogged by prior directions on preference for fair play

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Naidus case supra held that the Transport Authorities in dealing with applications for permits... discharge quasi-judicial functions... It is, therefore essential to fundamentals of fair-play in the administration of law that the decision of these Transport Authorities... should not be clogged by directions indicating the order of preference.

arguments.claim: Section 55 already provides preference to co-operative societies where conditions equal; Commission cannot expand via directions

anchor.surface_text: Section 55 of the Act which deals with applications for the public carriers permit states that other conditions being equal an application for a public carriers permit from a Co-operative Society, shall, as far as may, be given preference over the applications for grant of permits.

arguments.claim: The four powers under section 63A are separate and distinct; directions under 63A(2)(c) are administrative

anchor.surface_text: Section 63A of the Act speaks of various powers of the InterState Transport Commission... These four powers are separate and distinct.

arguments.claim: The directions specifying order of preference encroach on judicial discretion of Transport Authorities

anchor.surface_text: It is apparent that the order of preference indicated in the garb of directions is an encroachment upon the judicial discretion of the Transport Authorities in the matter of grant of permits.

arguments.claim: Commission has no power to issue directions fettering quasi-judicial functions under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was correct in holding that the Commission was not vested with any power to issue directions which may have the effect of fettering the Regional Transport Authorities or the State Transport Authorities concerned in performance of their quasi-judicial functions under the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Power under 63A(2)(c) limited to executive and administrative directions

anchor.surface_text: The power of the Inter-State Transport Commission under section 63A 2 c of the Act to issue directions is referable only to directions of executive and administrative nature.

holdings.text: The Commission was not vested with any power to issue directions which may have the effect of fettering the Regional Transport Authorities or the State Transport Authorities concerned in performance of their quasi-judicial functions under the provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was companyrect in holding that the Commission was number vested with any power to issue directions which may have the effect of fettering the Regional Transport Authorities or the State Transport Authorities companycerned in performance of their quasi-judicial functions under the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directions specifying order of preference encroach on judicial discretion; analogous to s43A in Naidu case where directions limited to administrative matters

holdings.text: The power of the Inter-State Transport Commission under section 63A 2 c of the Act to issue directions is referable only to directions of executive and administrative nature

anchor.surface_text: The power of the Inter-State Transport Commission under section 63A 2 c of the Act to issue directions is referable only to directions of executive and administrative nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s63A(2)(c) mirrors s43A; words 'directions' equivalent to executive acts; s63A(4) requires authorities to follow indicates administrative nature

holdings.text: The Commission has no power to entrench upon the quasi-judicial functions of the Transport Authorities in the matter of grant of permits

anchor.surface_text: The Commission has numberpower to entrench upon the quasi-judicial functions of the Transport Authorities in the matter of grant of permits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grant of permits is quasi-judicial; prior directions on preference violate fair play and natural justice

holdings.text: The order of the High Court in quashing the direction is upheld

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court in quashing the direction is upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly quashed directions as encroaching on quasi-judicial jurisdiction

holdings.text: In the absence of any power to enact subordinate legislation by way of rules the delegation of legislative power cannot be lightly inferred

holdings.reasoning_summary: No rule-making power conferred on Commission under s133(1); safeguards absent distinguish from legislative rules

holdings.text: The reasoning in Naidu's case applies to the interpretation of section 63A 2 c of the Act

anchor.surface_text: This companytention is unsound both on logic and principle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction based on 'directions' vs 'orders and directions' rejected; same logic and principle apply

holdings.text: Transport Authorities in dealing with applications for permits discharge quasi-judicial functions

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Naidus case supra held that the Transport Authorities in dealing with applications for permits... discharge quasi-judicial functions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmed from Naidu precedent; essential for fair play that decisions not clogged by prior preferences

holdings.text: The four powers under section 63A are separate and distinct

anchor.surface_text: These four powers are separate and distinct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme drafting shows distinct functions: schemes, disputes, directions, direct grant/revocation

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail.

precedents.cited_proposition: State Government under section 43A cannot issue directions prescribing criteria for selection and marking system for grant of permits as it interferes with quasi-judicial functions of Transport Authorities
precedents.cited_holding: the power of the State Government to issue orders and directions in respect of any matter relating to road transport to the State or Regional Transport Authorities did number embrace any power of the State Government to give directions in respect of matters which had been entrusted to the Tribunals companystituted under the Act and which are to be dealt with by those Authorities in quasi-judicial manner. The words orders and directions were held in that case to be equivalent to executive acts
